page.title: 14CLANNABOROUGH
page.content: Clannaborough today is only a quaint church used infrequently for services, and an adjacent farm, just off the road from Copplestone to Bow. However it has a history which goes back to pre-Roman times. It stands on the Celtic trackway north of Dartmoor, and the unusual circular churchyard may well have been a pre-Christian worshipping site. It is mentioned in the Domesday Book as Cloenesberg, held by Ralph of Pomeroy from Baldwin; Godman the priest held it before 1066; value 25 shillings. In 1239 it was called Clovenberge, which means "Cloven hill". Until recently, the parish was one of the smallest in the country, just 1 mile wide and 6 miles long. It is now in the parish of Down St Mary.
